revisions.rev:
{{Infobox dotcom company | company_name = Box.net | company_logo = [[Image:Box.net logo.gif|frameless]] | launch_date = [[2005]] in [[Mercer Island, WA|Mercer Island, Washington]] | location = [[Palo Alto, CA]] | Parent = [[GloboTech Corporation]] | key_people = Aaron Levie ([[Chief Executive Officer|CEO]])
Dylan Smith ([[Chief Financial Officer|CFO]]) | num_employees = 240[http://www.businessinsider.com/this-26-year-old-entrepreneur-has-raised-more-than-100-million-to-slay-the-giants-2011-8 This 26-Year Old Founder Is Raising $100 Million To Take On Giants Like Microsoft] | industry = [[Technology]] | url = {{url|www.box.net}} | alexa = {{decrease}} 1,050 ({{as of|2011|12|2|alt=December 2011}}){{cite web|url= http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/box.net |title= Box.net Site Info | publisher= [[Alexa Internet]] |accessdate= 2011-12-02 }} }} '''Box''' is an online [[File Sharing]] and Cloud [[Content Management]] service for enterprise companies. The company has adopted a [[freemium]] business model, and provides 5GB of free storage[http://www.networkcomputing.com/cloud-storage/boxnet-expands-capacity-and-services.php Box.net Expands Capacity And Services â Network Computing for personal accounts. A mobile version of the service is available for [[Android (operating system)|Android]], [[iPhone]], [[iPad]], [[BlackBerry]] and [[WebOS]] devices. ][http://www.computerworld.com/s/article/9146738/With_latest_features_Box.net_claims_edge_over_SharePoint_Google_Docs With latest features, Box.net claims edge over SharePoint, Google Docs â Computerworld] ==History== Box.net was founded in 2005 as a college business project by Aaron Levie (CEO) and Dylan Smith (CFO).[http://www.entrepreneur.com/magazine/entrepreneur/2010/august/207510.html I'm an Entrepreneur; Get Me Out of Here! | Entrepreneur.com] It was incorporated in April of that year. Originally based in [[Mercer Island, Washington]], Box.net moved to [[Palo Alto]], [[California]], in the summer of 2006. Box received [[angel capital]] from [[Mark Cuban]] in 2005, then raised a [[Series A]] round of $1.5 million from [[Draper Fisher Jurvetson]] in 2006. In late 2007, it raised a Series B round of $6 million and then another $7.1 million in 2009 from [[U.S. Venture Partners]] and Draper Fisher Jurvetson, bringing total investment to $14.6 million.[[Box.net#cite note-0]] In October 2009, Box.net acquired Increo Solutions, the developer of collaborative online document and media viewing tools Backboard and Embedit.in. As a result of this acquisition, Box.net launched two new features in January 2010: an integrated content viewer and the ability to embed these files anywhere on the web.[[Box.net#cite note-3]] In 2011, the company closed a $48 million funding round led by [[Meritech Capital Partners]], [[Andreessen Horowitz]], and Emergence Capital Partners. The $48 million included $10 million in debt financing from Hercules Technology Growth Capital.[http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-24/box-net-gets-48-million-equity-debt-investment-from-andreessen-meritech.html Box.net Receives $48 Million Investment, Led by Meritech â Bloomberg] "There was no capital limit and we could've raised more," said Mr. Levie.Pui-Wing Tam, & Amir Efrati. (2011, March 10). Web Start-Ups Get Upper Hand Over Investors --- VC Firms Drive Up Valuations, Attach Fewer Strings to Deals. Wall Street Journal (Eastern Edition), p. B.1. Retrieved March 24, 2011, from ABI/INFORM Global. (Document ID: 2287815741). ==API== In December 2007 the company launched its OpenBox platform, which connects content from Box.net with other web-based applications and services. Included in the launch were online services [[EchoSign]], [[Autodesk]], [[Zoho]], [[ThinkFree]], [[Scribd]], [[Picnik]], [[Zazzle]], [[Twitter]] and [[Myxer]]. Since then, new OpenBox services have been added from Salesforce, Google Apps, FedEx, Twitter, WatchDox, MindMeister, Fuze Meeting and others. There are now more than 60 OpenBox services available. With the launch of its OpenBox platform, Box.net added the ability for developers to create services that will interact with a user's files on Box.net. The [[Application Programming Interface|API]] is implemented over conventional [[XML]]; documentation is available at the OpenBox Developer Documentation Site. Box.net also launched its OpenBox Mobile developer program in September 2009, enabling developers to make mobile content accessible to other apps and services. iPhone application developers that utilize OpenBox Mobile include iThoughts, iBlueSky, JotNot, iRec, Pixelpipe, Smart Recorder, Readdle and Kinoma. ==Products== The core of the service is based around sharing, collaborating, and working with files that are uploaded to Box.net. Box.net offers 3 account types: Enterprise, Business and Personal.www.box.net/pricing Depending on the type of account, Box.net has a number of features such as unlimited storage, custom branding, administrative controls and 3rd party integrations with applications like Google apps, Gmail, NetSuite and Salesforce. The service also has a variety of social features such as discussions, groups and an update feed. == Reception == [[File:Aaron Levie, Co-founder and CEO, Box.jpg|thumb|Aaron Levie speaks at "The Cloud Rises: The Latest From a Ten-Year-Old Trend".]] In 2009, the Company was awarded the Silicon Valley / San Jose Business Journal's Emerging Tech award in the Cloud Computing category,{{cite news| url=http://www.bizjournals.com/sanjose/stories/2009/12/07/focus9.html | date=December 6, 2009 | title=Box.net lets you store, share, work in the computing cloud}} and has also been named a WebWare 100 Award winner in 2007 and 2008, and one of AlwaysOn's "AO Top Private Companies" for 2007.[http://www.scribd.com/doc/391175/The-2007-AlwaysOn-Top-100-Private-Companies The 2007 AlwaysOn Top 100 Private Companies] Co-founders Aaron Levie and Dylan Smith were among the top five finalists in Business Week's "Best Entrepreneurs 25 and Under" rankings for 2009.[http://www.businessweek.com/smallbiz/content/nov2009/sb2009119_604956.htm The Winning Young Entrepreneurs, 2009 â BusinessWeek] In 2009, Box.net was nominated "Best Enterprise Start-up" Crunchie In 2010,[http://news.cnet.com/webware/?keyword=Live+Mesh Live Mesh posts â Webware â CNET] and was recognized as one of the "Hottest Silicon Valley Companies" by Lead411.[http://www.lead411.com/silicon-valley-companies.html Hottest Silicon Valley Companies] == Media Appearances == The company's CEO, Aaron Levie, has had multiple articles featured on the Blog [[TechCrunch]].[http://techcrunch.com/2010/11/07/building-the-simple-enterprise/?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+Techcrunch+%28TechCrunch%29&utm_content=Twitter Building the Simple Enterprise | TechCrunch][http://techcrunch.com/2010/07/25/enterprise-software-is-sexy-again/ Enterprise Software Is Sexy Again | TechCrunch] He is also frequently invited to speak at industry events about Cloud computing and enterprise solutions.[http://www.web2expo.com/webexny2010/public/schedule/detail/15046 Freemium for Sale: 6 Reasons You'd be Crazy Not to Give Your Software Out for Free: Web 2.0 Expo New York 2010 â Co-produced by TechWeb & O'Reilly Conferences, September 27 â ...] The company's CFO, Dylan Smith, was featured on an episode of the reality TV show [[Millionaire Matchmaker]] in 2010.[http://www.bravotv.com/the-millionaire-matchmaker/season-3/hillel-and-dylan The Millionaire Matchmaker Season 3 â Episode 11 â Hillel and Dylan â Bravo TV
